question: 新た
userExplanationLong:
新しい atarashii Everyday "new". New in terms of time or recentness. Objects, ideas, or situations that are fresh, unused, or just recently introduced.

新た arata: More formal/literary. Implies a renewal or a fresh start. May imply that nothing similar has existed before. Often represents a change or a departure from the past. Carries a sense of beginning anew or refreshing something existing.
sourceMnemonic: This is the adjective version of the kanji <kanji>new</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>new</vocabulary> too.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your parents put a <vocabulary>newly</vocabulary> wrapped present under the Christmas tree. You don't want to wait to see what new thing they got you so you rip it open to find they got you <reading>a ra</reading>w (<ja>あら</ja>) steak. Getting a new steak is cool and all, but a raw steak is pretty gross. It's dripping blood all over the place.
